grammarPoints.usage: Use subjunctive mood after expressions of necessity
grammarPoints.example: Il faut que tu viennes
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: You must come

grammarPoints.usage: Use subjunctive when expressing wishes or desires about others
grammarPoints.example: Je veux que tu réussisses
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I want you to succeed

grammarPoints.usage: Use subjunctive after expressions of fear or doubt
grammarPoints.example: J'ai peur qu'il ne vienne pas
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I fear that he won't come

grammarPoints.usage: Use subjunctive after expressions of doubt
grammarPoints.example: Je doute qu'il soit capable
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I doubt that he is capable

grammarPoints.usage: Use subjunctive after concessive conjunctions
grammarPoints.example: Bien qu'il soit malade, il travaille
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Although he is sick, he works

grammarPoints.usage: Use subjunctive after conditional conjunctions
grammarPoints.example: Pourvu qu'il fasse beau demain
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Provided that the weather is nice tomorrow

grammarPoints.usage: Use subjunctive after temporal conjunctions expressing future time
grammarPoints.example: Il faut partir avant qu'il ne fasse nuit
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: We must leave before it gets dark

grammarPoints.usage: Use subjunctive after negative conditional conjunctions
grammarPoints.example: Il viendra à moins qu'il ne soit malade
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He will come unless he is sick

grammarPoints.usage: Express hypothetical or polite requests using the conditional mood
grammarPoints.example: Si j'avais de l'argent, j'achèterais une maison
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: If I had money, I would buy a house

grammarPoints.usage: Express hypothetical situations that didn't happen
grammarPoints.example: Si j'avais su, je n'aurais pas fait cela
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: If I had known, I wouldn't have done that

grammarPoints.usage: Describe an action that was ongoing in the past
grammarPoints.example: Depuis deux ans, elle habitait à Paris
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: For two years, she lived in Paris

grammarPoints.usage: Describe an action that was completed before another past action
grammarPoints.example: Il avait mangé avant que je n'arrive
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He had eaten before I arrived

grammarPoints.usage: Express an action that just happened
grammarPoints.example: Je viens de terminer mon travail
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I just finished my work

grammarPoints.usage: Express an action that will happen in the near future
grammarPoints.example: Je vais partir demain
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I am going to leave tomorrow

grammarPoints.pattern: pronoms relatifs qui, que, dont, où
grammarPoints.meaning: relative pronouns who, that, of which, where
grammarPoints.usage: Link clauses and provide more information about nouns
grammarPoints.example: L'homme qui parle est mon père
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The man who is speaking is my father

grammarPoints.pattern: pronoms relatifs composés lequel, auquel, duquel
grammarPoints.usage: Replace prepositional phrases in relative clauses
grammarPoints.example: Le crayon avec lequel tu écris est rouge
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The pencil with which you are writing is red

grammarPoints.pattern: pronoms complément d'objet indirect me, te, lui, nous, vous, leur
grammarPoints.usage: Replace nouns that are objects of prepositions like 'to' or 'for'
grammarPoints.example: Je lui ai donné un cadeau
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I gave him a gift

grammarPoints.pattern: pronoms complément d'objet direct le, la, l', les
grammarPoints.usage: Replace nouns that receive the action directly
grammarPoints.example: Je le vois tous les jours
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I see him every day

grammarPoints.pattern: pronoms réfléchis se, me, te, nous, vous
grammarPoints.usage: Express actions performed by the subject on themselves
grammarPoints.example: Elle se lave les mains
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: She washes her hands

grammarPoints.pattern: pronoms toniques moi, toi, lui, elle, nous, vous, eux, elles
grammarPoints.usage: Emphasize or follow prepositions
grammarPoints.example: C'est moi qui ai fait cela
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: It's me who did that

grammarPoints.pattern: y pour remplacer une chose ou un lieu
grammarPoints.meaning: y to replace a thing or place
grammarPoints.usage: Replace prepositional phrases with 'à' or location references
grammarPoints.example: Tu y vas demain? Oui, j'y vais
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Are you going there tomorrow? Yes, I'm going

grammarPoints.pattern: en pour remplacer une quantité ou une partie
grammarPoints.meaning: en to replace a quantity or part
grammarPoints.usage: Replace partitive nouns or phrases introduced by 'de'
grammarPoints.example: Vous avez du café? Oui, j'en ai
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Do you have coffee? Yes, I have some

grammarPoints.pattern: accord du participe passé avec l'objet direct
grammarPoints.meaning: agreement of past participle with direct object
grammarPoints.usage: Participle agrees with preceding direct object in compound tenses
grammarPoints.example: Les lettres que j'ai écrites
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The letters that I wrote

grammarPoints.pattern: accord du participe passé avec le sujet
grammarPoints.meaning: agreement of past participle with subject
grammarPoints.usage: Participle agrees with subject in reflexive verbs
grammarPoints.example: Elle s'est levée tôt
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: She got up early

grammarPoints.usage: Express actions performed by an agent on the subject
grammarPoints.example: Le livre est écrit par l'auteur
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The book is written by the author

grammarPoints.usage: Express completed actions in passive form
grammarPoints.example: Le projet a été terminé par l'équipe
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The project was completed by the team

grammarPoints.pattern: adjectifs comparatifs plus... que, moins... que, aussi... que
grammarPoints.usage: Compare qualities between two things
grammarPoints.example: Marie est plus intelligente que Jean
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Marie is more intelligent than Jean

grammarPoints.pattern: adjectifs superlatifs le plus, le moins
grammarPoints.usage: Express the highest or lowest degree of a quality
grammarPoints.example: C'est le plus beau jour de ma vie
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: It is the most beautiful day of my life

grammarPoints.usage: Compare actions or states between two things
grammarPoints.example: Il court plus vite que moi
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He runs faster than me

grammarPoints.pattern: adverbes superlatifs le plus, le moins
grammarPoints.usage: Express the highest or lowest degree of an action or state
grammarPoints.example: Il court le plus vite
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He runs the fastest

grammarPoints.usage: Use special comparative forms for 'good' and 'well'
grammarPoints.example: Ce livre est meilleur que celui-ci
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This book is better than that one

grammarPoints.usage: Know when to place adjectives before or after nouns
grammarPoints.example: Une belle maison rouge
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: A beautiful red house

grammarPoints.usage: Form plural adjectives to agree with plural nouns
grammarPoints.example: Les enfants intelligents
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The intelligent children

grammarPoints.usage: Recognize adjectives that don't change form
grammarPoints.example: Les robes chic, les costumes chic
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The chic dresses, the chic suits

grammarPoints.usage: Create adverbs from adjectives by adding -ment suffix
grammarPoints.example: intelligemment, facilement, rapidement
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: intelligently, easily, quickly

grammarPoints.usage: Learn adverbs that don't follow standard formation rules
grammarPoints.example: vite, bien, mal, peu, beaucoup
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: quickly, well, badly, little, much

grammarPoints.usage: Express simple negation
grammarPoints.example: Je ne suis pas fatigué
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I am not tired

grammarPoints.usage: Express that something never happens
grammarPoints.example: Il ne vient jamais à l'heure
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He never comes on time

grammarPoints.usage: Express that nothing happens or exists
grammarPoints.example: Je ne vois rien
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I see nothing

grammarPoints.usage: Express that no one does something
grammarPoints.example: Je ne connais personne ici
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I know nobody here

grammarPoints.usage: Express that something is no longer the case
grammarPoints.example: Il ne travaille plus
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He doesn't work anymore

grammarPoints.meaning: negation with ne... not a single
grammarPoints.usage: Express complete negation or absence
grammarPoints.example: Je n'ai aucune idée
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I have no idea

grammarPoints.usage: Use multiple negative structures together
grammarPoints.example: Il ne dit jamais rien à personne
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He never tells anything to anyone

grammarPoints.usage: Express amounts or quantities
grammarPoints.example: Tous les étudiants ont réussi
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: All students succeeded

grammarPoints.pattern: articles partitifs du, de la, de l', des
grammarPoints.usage: Refer to undefined quantities of nouns
grammarPoints.example: Je bois du café
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I drink coffee

grammarPoints.pattern: prépositions de lieu: à, en, dans, sous, sur, près de
grammarPoints.usage: Indicate location or position
grammarPoints.example: Le livre est sur la table
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The book is on the table

grammarPoints.pattern: prépositions de temps: à, en, pendant, depuis, pour
grammarPoints.usage: Express when or how long something happens
grammarPoints.example: Je l'attends depuis une heure
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I've been waiting for him for an hour

grammarPoints.pattern: contractions à + le, à + les, de + le, de + les
grammarPoints.usage: Combine prepositions with definite articles
grammarPoints.example: Je vais au cinéma, je reviens du parc
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I'm going to the cinema, I'm coming back from the park

grammarPoints.usage: Express present actions with regular -er verbs
grammarPoints.example: Je parle, tu parles, il parle
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I speak, you speak, he speaks

grammarPoints.usage: Express present actions with regular -ir verbs
grammarPoints.example: Je finis, tu finis, il finit
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I finish, you finish, he finishes

grammarPoints.usage: Express present actions with regular -re verbs
grammarPoints.example: Je vends, tu vends, il vend
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I sell, you sell, he sells

grammarPoints.pattern: présent de l'indicatif verbes irréguliers: avoir, être
grammarPoints.meaning: present indicative irregular verbs: to have, to be
grammarPoints.usage: Use common irregular auxiliary verbs
grammarPoints.example: J'ai, je suis, tu as, tu es
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I have, I am, you have, you are

grammarPoints.pattern: présent de l'indicatif verbes irréguliers: aller, faire, venir, pouvoir, devoir, vouloir
grammarPoints.usage: Use frequently used irregular verbs
grammarPoints.example: Je vais, tu fais, il vient, nous pouvons
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I go, you do, he comes, we can

grammarPoints.pattern: présent de l'indicatif verbes irréguliers: savoir, voir, dire, prendre
grammarPoints.usage: Use additional common irregular verbs
grammarPoints.example: Je sais, je vois, je dis, je prends
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I know, I see, I say, I take

grammarPoints.usage: Express completed past actions with avoir auxiliary
grammarPoints.example: J'ai mangé, tu as parlé, il a fini
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I ate, you spoke, he finished

grammarPoints.usage: Express completed past actions with être auxiliary (movement verbs)
grammarPoints.example: Je suis allé, tu es parti, elle est venue
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I went, you left, she came

grammarPoints.usage: Describe repeated or habitual past actions
grammarPoints.example: Je jouais au tennis chaque semaine
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I played tennis every week

grammarPoints.usage: Describe conditions or states in the past
grammarPoints.example: Il faisait beau, les enfants jouaient
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The weather was nice, the children were playing

grammarPoints.usage: Express actions that will happen
grammarPoints.example: Je parlerai, tu finiras, il vendra
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I will speak, you will finish, he will sell

grammarPoints.usage: Form future tense with irregular stems
grammarPoints.example: Je serai, je ferai, j'irai, je pourrai
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I will be, I will do, I will go, I will be able

grammarPoints.usage: Form subjunctive mood for regular verbs
grammarPoints.example: que je parle, que tu finisses, qu'il vende
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: that I speak, that you finish, that he sells

grammarPoints.pattern: présent du subjonctif verbes irréguliers: être, avoir, aller, faire
grammarPoints.usage: Form subjunctive mood for common irregular verbs
grammarPoints.example: que je sois, que j'aie, que j'aille, que je fasse
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: that I be, that I have, that I go, that I do

grammarPoints.usage: Give commands or instructions
grammarPoints.example: Parle!, Finissons!, Vendez!
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Speak!, Let's finish!, Sell!

grammarPoints.usage: Use pronouns in imperative sentences
grammarPoints.example: Dis-le moi!, Donne-lui le livre!
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Tell me!, Give him the book!

grammarPoints.usage: Express simultaneous or causative actions
grammarPoints.example: En sortant, j'ai oublié mes clés
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: While leaving, I forgot my keys

grammarPoints.usage: Form verbal adjectives or use in literary descriptions
grammarPoints.example: L'enfant courant dans le parc
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The child running in the park

grammarPoints.usage: Form noun phrases to modify other nouns
grammarPoints.example: Une tasse de café, un professeur de français
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: A cup of coffee, a French teacher

grammarPoints.meaning: concordance of tenses in the past
grammarPoints.usage: Use correct tense combinations in complex sentences with past context
grammarPoints.example: Il a dit qu'il était fatigué
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He said he was tired

grammarPoints.usage: Report what someone says without direct quotation
grammarPoints.example: Il dit qu'il est heureux
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He says that he is happy

grammarPoints.usage: Report past statements with correct tense shifts
grammarPoints.example: Il a dit qu'il était heureux
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He said that he was happy

grammarPoints.usage: Form questions by inverting subject and verb
grammarPoints.example: Parlez-vous français?
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Do you speak French?

grammarPoints.usage: Form questions using 'is it that' structure
grammarPoints.example: Est-ce que tu parles français?
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Do you speak French?

grammarPoints.usage: Use who, what, where, when, why, how in questions
grammarPoints.example: Où allez-vous? Pourquoi partez-vous?
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Where are you going? Why are you leaving?

grammarPoints.pattern: exclamations avec quel, quels, quelle, quelles
grammarPoints.usage: Express surprise or emotion
grammarPoints.example: Quel beau jour!
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: What a beautiful day!

grammarPoints.pattern: conjonctions et, ou, mais, donc, car
grammarPoints.usage: Connect words, phrases, or clauses of equal importance
grammarPoints.example: Je suis fatigué mais je vais continuer
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I am tired but I will continue

grammarPoints.usage: Express contrast or contradiction
grammarPoints.example: Il est riche, pourtant il n'est pas heureux
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He is rich, yet he is not happy

grammarPoints.pattern: conjonctions de subordination que, si, parce que
grammarPoints.usage: Connect main clauses with dependent clauses
grammarPoints.example: Je sais que tu es occupé, je partis parce qu'il pleuvait
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I know that you are busy, I left because it was raining

grammarPoints.usage: Express conditional relationships
grammarPoints.example: Si tu étudies, alors tu réussiras
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: If you study, then you will succeed

grammarPoints.usage: Express concession despite opposition
grammarPoints.example: Bien qu'il pleuve, nous sortons
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Although it's raining, we're going out

grammarPoints.usage: Express precautionary or hypothetical situations
grammarPoints.example: Je t'appelle au cas où tu aurais besoin
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I'll call you in case you need something

grammarPoints.usage: Ask or explain reasons using infinitives
grammarPoints.example: Pourquoi ne pas venir demain?
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Why not come tomorrow?

grammarPoints.pattern: structures être en train de + infinitif
grammarPoints.meaning: to be in the process of structure
grammarPoints.usage: Emphasize that an action is currently happening
grammarPoints.example: Je suis en train de lire
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I am (in the process of) reading

grammarPoints.usage: Express an action that just happened
grammarPoints.example: Je viens de manger
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I just ate

grammarPoints.usage: Express an action that will happen soon
grammarPoints.example: Je vais partir
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I'm going to leave

grammarPoints.usage: Express obligation or probability
grammarPoints.example: Je dois partir demain
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I must leave tomorrow

grammarPoints.usage: Express possibility or permission
grammarPoints.example: Peux-tu m'aider?
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Can you help me?

grammarPoints.usage: Express wishes or desires
grammarPoints.example: Je veux apprendre le français
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I want to learn French

grammarPoints.usage: Express boldness or courage
grammarPoints.example: Il ose dire la vérité
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He dares to tell the truth

grammarPoints.usage: Express permission or causation
grammarPoints.example: Je la laisse partir
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I let her leave

grammarPoints.usage: Express causation or having something done
grammarPoints.example: Il fait réparer la voiture
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He has the car repaired

grammarPoints.usage: Express perception of actions
grammarPoints.example: Je le regarde travailler
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I watch him work

grammarPoints.usage: Express perception of actions or states
grammarPoints.example: J'ai vu partir le train
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I saw the train leave

grammarPoints.usage: Ensure verb agrees with its subject in number and person
grammarPoints.example: Les enfants jouent, l'enfant joue
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The children play, the child plays

grammarPoints.usage: Handle agreement with collective nouns
grammarPoints.example: La plupart des étudiants sont venus
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Most of the students came

grammarPoints.usage: Use plural verb with subjects joined by 'and'
grammarPoints.example: Pierre et Marie sont arrivés
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Peter and Mary arrived

grammarPoints.usage: Use singular or plural verb with subjects joined by 'or'
grammarPoints.example: Pierre ou Marie est venu(e)
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Peter or Mary came

grammarPoints.meaning: gender and number agreement with nouns
grammarPoints.usage: Ensure articles and adjectives agree with nouns
grammarPoints.example: Une belle maison, des beaux jardins
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: A beautiful house, beautiful gardens

grammarPoints.usage: Learn nouns with unexpected gender
grammarPoints.example: une main, un problème, un système
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: a hand, a problem, a system

grammarPoints.pattern: verbes prépositionnels: dépendre de, compter sur
grammarPoints.usage: Use verbs that require specific prepositions
grammarPoints.example: Je dépends de toi, je compte sur lui
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I depend on you, I count on him

grammarPoints.pattern: verbes avec deux objets: donner quelque chose à quelqu'un
grammarPoints.usage: Use verbs that take both direct and indirect objects
grammarPoints.example: Je te donne un livre
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I give you a book

grammarPoints.usage: Use possessive modifiers before nouns
grammarPoints.example: Mon livre, ta maison, son ami
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: My book, your house, his/her friend

grammarPoints.usage: Ensure possessives agree with nouns
grammarPoints.example: Mon ami, ma soeur, mes enfants
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: My friend, my sister, my children

grammarPoints.pattern: adjectifs démonstratifs: ce, cet, cette, ces
grammarPoints.usage: Point out specific nouns
grammarPoints.example: Ce livre, cet arbre, cette maison
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This book, this tree, this house

grammarPoints.pattern: adjectifs indéfinis: un, une, des vs quelque, plusieurs
grammarPoints.usage: Modify nouns with indefinite quantity
grammarPoints.example: Quelques personnes, plusieurs jours
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Some people, several days

grammarPoints.pattern: adjectifs interrogatifs: quel, quelle, quels, quelles
grammarPoints.usage: Ask about specific nouns
grammarPoints.example: Quel livre? Quelle heure?
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Which book? What time?

grammarPoints.pattern: adjectifs exclamatifs: quel, quelle, quels, quelles
grammarPoints.usage: Express surprise or emotion about nouns
grammarPoints.example: Quel dommage!, Quelle beauté!
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: What a shame!, What beauty!

grammarPoints.pattern: pronoms référents: le, la, l' après avoir/être
grammarPoints.usage: Replace nouns with pronouns after auxiliaries
grammarPoints.example: Je l'ai vu, il l'est devenu
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I saw him, he became it

grammarPoints.pattern: construction c'est moi: C'est moi qui, C'est toi qui
grammarPoints.usage: Emphasize subjects using c'est
grammarPoints.example: C'est moi qui suis venu
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: It's me who came

grammarPoints.pattern: emploi de celui-ci et celui-là dans contexte
grammarPoints.usage: Distinguish between nearby and distant objects
grammarPoints.example: Celui-ci est neuf, celui-là est ancien
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This one is new, that one is old

grammarPoints.usage: Connect temporal or locational information
grammarPoints.example: La maison où j'habite, le jour où je suis né
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The house where I live, the day when I was born

grammarPoints.usage: Add additional information about nouns with commas
grammarPoints.example: Mon ami Pierre, qui est très intelligent, a réussi
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: My friend Peter, who is very intelligent, succeeded

grammarPoints.usage: Use inversion for formal questions
grammarPoints.example: Avez-vous des questions?
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Do you have questions?

grammarPoints.usage: Use consecutive negatives for emphasis
grammarPoints.example: Il n'y a pas ne serait-ce qu'une faute
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: There isn't even a single mistake

grammarPoints.pattern: emploi de tout comme pronom et déterminant
grammarPoints.usage: Use 'all' in various grammatical positions
grammarPoints.example: Tout est possible, tous les enfants
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Everything is possible, all the children

grammarPoints.pattern: complément de nom avec de ou par
grammarPoints.usage: Modify nouns with prepositional phrases
grammarPoints.example: Une tasse de café, un professeur de langues
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: A cup of coffee, a language teacher

grammarPoints.usage: Place pronouns after imperative verbs
grammarPoints.example: Dis-moi, explique-le-moi
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Tell me, explain it to me

grammarPoints.usage: Express multiple negations
grammarPoints.example: Je n'aime ni le café ni le thé
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I like neither coffee nor tea

grammarPoints.usage: Express repeated or habitual actions in present
grammarPoints.example: Chaque jour, il va au travail
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Every day, he goes to work

grammarPoints.usage: Distinguish between just-finished and ongoing past
grammarPoints.example: Je viens de manger vs je mangeais
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I just ate vs I was eating

grammarPoints.pattern: verbes pronominaux réfléchis: se laver, se coucher
grammarPoints.usage: Express actions done to oneself
grammarPoints.example: Je me lave les mains, tu te couches
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I wash my hands, you go to bed
